chapter.title: Creating Operating System Images
chapter.para: There are multiple ways to create custom operating system images from &s4s;. The preferred way is generally to use &kiwi; which ingests an XML configuration file and then runs fully automatically.
Alternatively, you can also create an image from an existing installation that is cleaned up before re-use.

sect1.title: Creating Images with &kiwi;
sect1.para: &kiwi; is a tool to create operating system images that can be easily copied to new physical or virtual machines. This section will present information on creating &s4sa; images with &kiwi;.
&sles4sap; now supports creating images with &kiwi; using the template from the package kiwi-template-sap. However, there are certain restrictions in the current implementation:

listitem.para: Only building VMX disk images is supported. Building other image types is not supported.
You must provide an ISO image of &sles4sap; at /tmp/SLES4SAP.iso. The &obs; does not contain all necessary packages.

sect1.title: Cleaning Up an Instance Before Using It as a Master Image
sect1.para: In some cases, it makes sense to use an image of an already-configured master instance on multiple systems instead of generating a &kiwi; image from scratch. For example, when your image needs to contain additional software or configuration that cannot be installed using &kiwi;.
However, normally such an image would contain certain configuration data that should not be copied along with the rest of the system.
To avoid needing to clean up manually, use the script &cmcu; (available from the package of the same name).
It deletes the following data automatically:

listitem.para: Swap device (zero-wiped, then re-enabled)
SUSE registration information and repositories from SUSE, and the Zypper ID
User and host SSH keys and domain and host names
The generated HANA-Firewall script (but not the configuration itself)
Shell history, mails, cron jobs, temporary files (/tmp, /var/tmp), log files (/var/log), random seeds, &systemd; Journal, collectd statistics, postfix configuration, parts of /root
/var/cache, /var/crash, /var/lib/systemd/coredump

sect1.para: Additionally, the following configuration is restored to defaults:

listitem.para: Network interfaces that do not use DHCP and network configuration (/etc/hostname, /etc/hosts, and /etc/resolv.conf)
sudo settings

sect1.para: Additionally, you can choose to set up a new &rootuser; password. UUID-based entries in /etc/fstab are replaced by device strings. This script also ensures that, if the first-boot section of the installation workflow was used for the original installation, it is run again on the next boot.

sect2.title: Configuring &cmcu;
sect2.para: Before running &cmcu;, the script can be configured in the following ways:

listitem.para: To configure the script to not clean up certain data, use the configuration file /etc/sysconfig/clone-master-clean-up.
This file also gives short explanations of the available options.
To configure the script to clean up additional directories or files, create a list with the absolute paths of such directories and files:
Save this list as /var/adm/clone-master-clean-up/custom_remove.
